19/ Dividing reward by risk, we get the # SharpeRatio or "risk-adjusted returns," for which # bitcoin has consistently outperformed the other asset classes.pic.twitter.com/wgVMXQceaX

18/ On the *reward* part of risk-reward, # bitcoin has stomped other asset classes, included @ facebook @ amazon @ netflix & @ Google stock (image from book: https://www.amazon.com/Cryptoassets-Innovative-Investors-Bitcoin-Beyond/dp/1260026671 …)pic.twitter.com/pktjTLdRCS
17/ 2016 was an example of how much # bitcoin’s volatility has dropped, as it was less volatile than @ twitter stock & on par with oil (as represented by $ USO)pic.twitter.com/2CIC3wRPoX

16/ Turning to risk-reward ratios, we first have volatility, which as I’ve discussed before shows a nice long-term downtrend as the liquidity deepens in the # bitcoin markets. While 2017 has been more volatile than 2016…pic.twitter.com/Asp5c7F0W6

15/ One year rolling average correlations show the same pattern of # bitcoin being indifferent to the movement of traditional asset classes. http://research.ark-invest.com/bitcoin-asset-class … (graph from original asset class white paper)pic.twitter.com/kt7pBVwVpR

14/ A giveaway for # cryptoassets representing an emerging asset class (unlike any existing asset class) are the correlations. # Bitcoin near zero correlated with all others. Graph from the book: https://www.amazon.com/Cryptoassets-Innovative-Investors-Bitcoin-Beyond/dp/1260026671 …pic.twitter.com/iCPay4e66L
13/ While some may want to debate the assumptions that go into calculating this ratio, it reveals to me that fiat currencies are more actively speculated upon *on a relative basis* than # bitcoin.

12/ Ratio of trading to transacting can reveal which asset is being speculated upon more on a relative basis. Global FX volumes are 10x greater (~$750T/yr) than global GDP (~$80T in 2017), while global bitcoin trading (~$1.4B/day) is only 2x > transaction volume (~$750B/day).pic.twitter.com/CRFD9cVw3j

11/ If you're still stuck on # bitcoin only being used for nefarious activity, then you should update your views as that's an overplayed & outdated story: https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=2808762 …pic.twitter.com/QpFbZHfbrt
10/ In other words, # bitcoin moves a half a million dollars worth of value around the world per minute, and that’s up 5x from 2016, which was up 2x from 2015.

9/ *transaction* value per min: 2017: $513,647 2016: $109,910 2015: $50,770 2014: $43,478 2013: $28,368 2012: $1,149 2011: $821 # bitcoin as a means of exchange. (graph is log scale)pic.twitter.com/F38GCS0ydt
8/ In other words, # bitcoin's mathematically metered supply schedule is superior to the whims of man controlling gold & fiat supply (graph from original white paper)pic.twitter.com/gB39BLHsD3

7/ # Bitcoin is often compared to gold, but gold’s supply = slightly inflationary, bitcoin’s supply = disinflationary going on deflationary. $ BTC better set up as a store of value.pic.twitter.com/qU6G0Bvu5q
6/ Note that the chart showed was only for # bitcoin. # Cryptoassets as a whole regularly trade north of $10B in daily volume.

5/ First bar an asset class has to clear is being sufficiently liquid so as to be relevant, measured here in # bitcoin’s daily trading volumes. For the last 50 days straight, $ BTC has traded > $1B, and the 2017 average is $1.4B+.pic.twitter.com/jaRzTrgmRL
